parts.text:
The image shows a student before and after a bungee jump. The bungee cord has an unstretched length of 20 m.

For safety reasons, it is important that the bungee cord used is appropriate for the student’s weight. Give two reasons why.
markScheme: 1 mark: The bungee cord might **snap** / extension could be too great.
1 mark: The student might **hit the river/ground** if the cord extends too much.

energy. When falling, the student's store of

parts.text: At the lowest point in the jump the student is stationary. The extension of the bungee cord is 35 m. The bungee cord behaves like a spring with spring constant 40 N/m. Calculate the energy stored in the stretched bungee cord.

questions.title: Energy stores during a bungee jump
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: In position B, the student is moving towards the river and the bungee cord is stretching. Compared with position A, how does the student’s gravitational potential energy change?
Compared with position A, how does the student’s kinetic energy change at position B?
Compared with position A, how does the bungee cord’s elastic potential energy change at position B?
The bungee cord behaves like a spring with spring constant 78.4 N/m. The extension is 25 m. Calculate the elastic potential energy stored by the bungee cord.
Bungee cord C will have a smaller extension than A or B for any bungee jumper. Give the reason why.
markScheme: 1 mark: It has the **greatest spring constant** (needs the largest force per metre to stretch).

parts.text: Which bungee cord would be safest to use for a person with a large weight?
Give a reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: It has the **greatest maximum extension before snapping**.

parts.text: There is a layer of water between the sled and the slide. How does the layer of water affect the friction between the sled and the slide?
The mass of one rider is 62.5 kg. The height of the slide is 16.0 m. Gravitational field strength = 9.8 N/kg. Calculate the gravitational potential energy at the top of the slide.
At the bottom of the slide the speed is 12 m/s. The mass is 62.5 kg. Calculate the kinetic energy at the bottom of the slide.
When a rider reaches the bottom of the slide, the sled decelerates and stops. Give two factors that will affect how far the sled will move before it stops.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any relevant factor, e.g. **speed at bottom** / **mass** / **friction** / **air resistance**.

questions.title: Zip wire and gravitational potential energy
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: The figure shows a person sliding down a zip wire. Describe how the vertical height of the tower could be measured accurately.
markScheme: 1 mark: Use a tape measure/metre rule/laser measure.
1 mark: Ensure vertical (e.g. set square/plumb line) or two people top/bottom or repeat and take a mean.

parts.text: The person moved through a vertical height of 2.0 m. Mass = 45 kg. Gravitational field strength = 9.8 N/kg. Calculate the change in gravitational potential energy.
Give three factors that affected the kinetic energy of the person as she reached the bottom of the zip wire.
markScheme: 1 mark: Any relevant factor, e.g. change in vertical **height**.

parts.text: In the USA, drones are not allowed to be flown too high above the ground. Suggest one possible risk of flying a drone too high above the ground.
markScheme: 1 mark: Identify a risk, e.g. **damage to aircraft** / **falling drone could injure people** / **damage buildings**.
1 mark: Explain the risk, e.g. drone could be sucked into engine / drone has more GPE at height so more damage on impact.

questions.topic: Energy transfers on a zip wire
questions.title: Zip wire: energy losses and different speeds
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: As the person moves down the zip wire, her increase in kinetic energy is less than her decrease in gravitational potential energy. Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: Work done against air resistance and/or friction (zip line and pulley).
1 mark: Energy transferred to the surroundings as thermal energy.

parts.text: Different people have different speeds at the end of the zip wire. Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: Different surface areas/body positions → different air resistance/drag.
1 mark: So energy transfer to surroundings differs, giving different final speeds.

parts.text: The graph shows velocity against time for a ball that is dropped and then bounces (air resistance ignored). Describe the motion of the ball between points A and B.
markScheme: 1 mark: The acceleration is **uniform/constant** (straight line on v-t graph).

parts.text: What direction is the ball moving between points C and D on the graph?
The ball and the Earth form a system. What is meant by ‘a system’?
options: A group of objects that interact.
Objects with big differences in mass.
markScheme: Answer: A group of objects that interact.

parts.text: When the ball hits the ground, energy is transferred from the ball to the Earth. Explain how the data in the graph shows this energy transfer.
markScheme: 1 mark: Velocity just after the bounce is **less** than just before.
1 mark: So the ball has **lost energy**.
1 mark: Reference to loss of **kinetic energy** / reduced GPE.
1 mark: Total energy of the ball–Earth system is **conserved**.

parts.text: A volume of $2.3 \times 10^4\,\text{m}^3$ of air passes the blades each second. The density of air is $1.2\,\text{kg/m}^3$. Calculate the mass of air passing the blades per second.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct rearrangement: $m = \rho V$ (from $\rho = m / V$)

parts.text: The power output is directly proportional to the kinetic energy of the air passing the blades each second. Describe the effect on the power output when the wind speed is halved.
markScheme: 1 mark: Mass of air per second is **halved** → KE factor 2 decrease.
1 mark: Wind speed halved → $v^2$ quartered → KE factor **4** decrease.
1 mark: Overall KE (and so power) decreases by a factor of **8**.

parts.text: The baby bouncer is a harness attached to a spring that hangs from a door frame. The baby bouncer should not be used with babies that have a mass greater than 12 kg. Suggest one reason why.
markScheme: 1 mark: The spring may become permanently extended / may break / extension may be too great.

parts.text: In positions A and B the baby is stationary. Describe the energy transfers as the baby moves from position A to position B.
markScheme: 1 mark: At A the baby has gravitational potential energy.
1 mark: As the baby moves down, energy transfers to kinetic energy and then to elastic potential energy in the spring.
1 mark: At B (stationary) energy stored as elastic potential energy (ignore dissipated energy).
